action.action-desc: Mr. Nadler (for himself and Mr. Correa) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and the Workforce, and in addition to the Committees on Energy and Commerce, and the Judiciary, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To prohibit agreements between employers that directly restrict the current or future employment of any employee.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the End Employer Collusion Act.

section.header: Unfair methods on competition relating to restrictive employment agreements

paragraph.text: The term employer has the meaning given the term in section 3 of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 (29 U.S.C. 203).
The termrestrictive employment agreement means any agreement that—

subparagraph.text: is between 2 or more employers, including through a franchise agreement or a contractor-subcontractor agreement; and
prohibits or restricts one such employer from soliciting or hiring the employees or former employees of another such employer.

subsection.text: It shall be unlawful for any entity to—

paragraph.text: enter into a restrictive employment agreement; or
enforce or threaten to enforce a restrictive employment agreement.

subparagraph.text: Any person who violates subsection (b) shall be liable to any individual harmed as a result of such violation in an amount equal to the sum—

clause.text: of any actual damages sustained by the individual as a result of the violation;
such amount of punitive damages as the court may allow; and
in the case of any successful action to enforce any liability under this section, the costs of the action and any reasonable attorney’s fees, as determined by the court.

subparagraph.text: An individual described in subparagraph (A) may bring a civil action under subparagraph (A) in any appropriate district court of the United States.

The Commission shall enforce this section in the same manner, by the same means, and with the same jurisdiction, powers, and duties as though all applicable terms and provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. 41 et seq.) were incorporated into and made a part of this section.
Any person who violates subsection (b) shall be subject to the penalties and entitled to the privileges and immunities provided in the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. 41 et seq.).
